Exercise 19.8

  2. Given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, we can just set δ=ε\delta = \varepsilonδ=ε. If ∣x−y∣<δ\abs{x - y} < \delta∣x−y∣<δ, then by (1), we have

Exercise 28.16

Let fff be a function defined on an open interval III containing aaa. Show f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) exists if and only if there is a function ε(x)\varepsilon\p{x}ε(x) defined on III such that

f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)[f′(a)−ε(x)]andlim⁡x→aε(x)=0.f\p{x} - f\p{a} = \p{x - a}\br{f'\p{a} - \varepsilon\p{x}} \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} = 0.f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)[f′(a)−ε(x)]andx→alim​ε(x)=0.
Solution.

"  ⟹  \implies⟹"

Assume f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) exists; that is, the limit

lim⁡x→af(x)−f(a)x−a\lim_{x\to a} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a}x→alim​x−af(x)−f(a)​

exists. Let

ε(x)≔{f′(a)−f(x)−f(a)x−aif a≠0,0if a=0.\varepsilon\p{x} \coloneqq \begin{cases} f'\p{a} - \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a} & \text{if } a \neq 0, \\ 0 & \text{if } a = 0. \end{cases}ε(x):={f′(a)−x−af(x)−f(a)​0​if a=0,if a=0.​

(You can figure this out by just solving for ε(x)\varepsilon\p{x}ε(x) in the equation they give you. Also, it doesn't matter what the value of ε(a)\varepsilon\p{a}ε(a) is as long as you define it.) Then it's easy to check that

f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)[f′(a)−ε(x)],f\p{x} - f\p{a} = \p{x - a}\br{f'\p{a} - \varepsilon\p{x}},f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)[f′(a)−ε(x)],

so it remains to check that lim⁡x→aε(x)=0\lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} = 0limx→a​ε(x)=0. By limit laws, it exists and

lim⁡x→aε(x)=lim⁡x→a[f′(a)−f(x)−f(a)x−a]=f′(a)−lim⁡x→af(x)−f(a)x−a=f′(a)−f′(a)=0.\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} &= \lim_{x\to a} \br{f'\p{a} - \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a}} \\ &= f'\p{a} - \lim_{x\to a} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a} \\ &= f'\p{a} - f'\p{a} \\ &= 0. \end{aligned}x→alim​ε(x)​=x→alim​[f′(a)−x−af(x)−f(a)​]=f′(a)−x→alim​x−af(x)−f(a)​=f′(a)−f′(a)=0.​

"  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

Suppose there exist a number L∈RL \in \RL∈R and a function ε(x)\varepsilon\p{x}ε(x) such that

f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)[L−ε(x)]andlim⁡x→aε(x)=0.f\p{x} - f\p{a} = \p{x - a}\br{L - \varepsilon\p{x}} \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} = 0.f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)[L−ε(x)]andx→alim​ε(x)=0.

By limit laws again fff is differentiable at aaa with

lim⁡x→af(x)−f(a)x−a=lim⁡x→a[L−ε(x)]=L−lim⁡x→aε(x)=L.\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\to a} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a} &= \lim_{x\to a} \br{L - \varepsilon\p{x}} \\ &= L - \lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} \\ &= L. \end{aligned}x→alim​x−af(x)−f(a)​​=x→alim​[L−ε(x)]=L−x→alim​ε(x)=L.​

Common Mistakes

The most common mistake I saw was trying to do something like this to try to show that lim⁡x→aε(x)=0\lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} = 0limx→a​ε(x)=0:

f′(a)=lim⁡x→a[f(x)−f(a)x−a]=lim⁡x→a[f′(a)−ε(x)]=f′(a)−lim⁡x→aε(x).f'\p{a} = \lim_{x\to a} \br{\frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a}} = \lim_{x\to a} \br{f'\p{a} - \varepsilon\p{x}} = f'\p{a} - \lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x}.f′(a)=x→alim​[x−af(x)−f(a)​]=x→alim​[f′(a)−ε(x)]=f′(a)−x→alim​ε(x).

Thus, solving gives lim⁡x→aε(x)=0\lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x} = 0limx→a​ε(x)=0.

The issue with this is that the argument only says this: if lim⁡x→aε(x)\lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x}limx→a​ε(x) exists, then it must be 000. However, you need to show that lim⁡x→aε(x)\lim_{x\to a} \varepsilon\p{x}limx→a​ε(x) exists to begin with. In other words, you can't just take limits on both sides and solve. The easiest way to do this is to use limit laws, which tells you that the limit exists and tells you have to compute the limit--you kill two birds with one stone.

This argument can be fixed, though it requires a little bit of work. See the following exercise.
